results.justification: The document explicitly states the goal of developing methods to estimate student knowledge and predict correctness in dialogues. The overall approach is clearly outlined.
Sections 4.1, 4.2, and 4.3 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the experimental design, including data annotation, LLMKT method, and DKT-Sem method.
The document mentions using the CoMTA and MathDial datasets, which are publicly available. The authors acknowledge other datasets exist as well.
Table 1 provides statistics for the datasets, including the number of dialogues, labels, KCs, and turns. This serves as a basic data dictionary.
The document describes the data collection methods for both CoMTA and MathDial, including how the dialogues were generated and the source of the data (Khan Academy, GPT-3.5, crowd workers).

The document states: "We release our prompts in an online supplementary material: https://osf.io/873ms?view_only=f32472a6560649e692a4e2ba603ef52c" and mentions using pyKT and pyBKT, which are open-source repositories.
The document mentions using scripts for data cleaning, analysis, and visualization, and links to the supplementary material where these are available.

The document describes statistical tests (accuracy, AUC, F1), models (DKT, DKVMN, AKT, SAINT, simpleKT, LLMKT, DKT-Sem, BKT), and reports effect sizes (accuracy, AUC, F1 scores) and standard deviations.
Section 6.2 provides a qualitative case study analysis of a dialogue, offering subjective context and interpretation of the model's predictions.
Table 2 presents the quantitative results of the experiments, clearly showing the performance of each method on both datasets.
Section 6.1 discusses limitations, such as the small size of the CoMTA dataset and the challenges of dialogueKT compared to standard KT. Section 7.2 details errors in the GPT-4o annotations.
